channel.title: Enumeration

item.title: Enumeration
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Galook, post:4, topic:3034”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=3449.msg33839#msg33839 date=1148041372]

switch (var) { firstVar: statement; break; secondVar: statement; break; }
[/quote]
yeah, i remember those rules, but i mean that they are a little different with enumerations, you can put in strings as var i think.[/quote]

switch(Gender) { MALE: statement; break; FEMALE: statement; break; Default: ... }

Read full topic

item.title: Enumeration
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I just want to add that there’s no reason why you can’t have an enumeration declaration within a class: you are allowed inner classes, and so inner enumerations are fine too.

Also, you can’t have a String type as the variable in a switch block…it has to be integer based, and so enumeration types are allowed since their values sorted by integer index I believe.

Read full topic

item.title: Enumeration
item.dc:creator: @muerte4 muerte4
item.description:
@muerte4 wrote:

pretty easy question but i’m stuck


public class Person {

public enum Gender { MALE, FEMALE };

private Gender g;

public Person(Gender g) {
this.g = g;
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
Person p = new Person(what do i put here?);
}
}

So basically what do I pass as an argument into the constructor? I tried just MALE, but i get can not find variable MALE

help greatly appreciated =D

Read full topic
